item.title: China and India Are Sitting Out Refugee Crisis
item.description: Asia’s giants could play leadership roles but see it as a losing issue that could diminish their clout and bilateral interests.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Ye Aung Thu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Migrants found at sea were escorted across the Bangladesh border to Rakhine State in Myanmar this month. Persecution has driven thousands from Myanmar.

item.title: Polo Fades in India on the Backs of Endangered Ponies
item.description: The decline of polo and of the Manipuri pony, which was once used in warfare and is now endangered, began when state patronage for polo players ended, around the time of India’s annexation of Manipur.
item.dc:creator: IAN THOMAS JANSEN-LONNQUIST

item.title: Greece Will Shut Banks in Fallout From Debt Crisis
item.description: The prime minister’s decisions escalated tensions and uncertainty over a financial crisis that some analysts say could have global ripples.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Cabinet members applauded Greece's prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, on Sunday amid debate over a bailout referendum.

item.title: Puerto Rico’s Governor Says Island’s Debts Are ‘Not Payable’
item.description: Gov. Alejandro García Padilla said that his administration would probably seek significant concessions from its creditors on a $72 billion debt load.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL CORKERY and MARY WILLIAMS WALSH
item.media:credit: Dennis Rivera for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Alejandro García Padilla plans to discuss the island’s fiscal crisis on a televised broadcast on Monday night.

item.title: French Assailant Texted Beheading Photo to Canadian Number
item.description: French authorities said Yassine Salhi, 35, accused in the beheading and an explosion at an American chemical factory in southeastern France, used a smartphone app to send a photo of himself with the victim’s head.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:description: French police officers on Sunday escorted Yassine Salhi, the suspect in a chemical factory attack in Saint Quentin-Fallavier.

item.title: Tunisian Gunman Showed Subtle Signs of Radicalization
item.description: Seifeddine Rezgui, the Tunisian student who shot 39 tourists at a seaside hotel on Friday, was a break-dancer in his youth but turned to extremism while in college.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL and FARAH SAMTI
item.media:description: Tourists on Sunday placed flowers on the beach near the Imperial Marhaba hotel in Sousse, Tunisia, where a gunman killed 39 people on Friday.

item.title: Afghan President Appoints a Second Female Governor
item.description: Even though his first appointee has been unable to take office because of protests, President Ashraf Ghani picked another woman as a provincial leader.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and AHMAD SHAKIB

item.title: Memo From Argentina: Some Fear Departing Argentine President Has No Plans of Really Leaving
item.description: President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner’s second term ends in December, but she has already endorsed a successor she hopes to influence, experts say.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:description: Cristina Fernández de Kirchner at an event in May.

item.title: Cash Withdrawals and Hoarding as Default Looms Over Greece
item.description: The response to the breakdown of negotiations in Brussels was a blend of anxiety and defiance, fear and weary resignation, but also an angry pride.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY and ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS
item.media:description: Graffiti on a street in central Athens on Sunday. The European Central Bank said it would not expand an emergency loan program that has been propping up Greek banks in recent weeks while the government was trying to reach a new debt deal with international creditors.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: You’re Better Than This, Europe
item.description: Shirking the obligation to protect refugees betrays our core values.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: NILS MUIZNIEKS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Pope's Ecological Vow
item.description: Climate change skeptics may well find that in Francis they have met their most formidable opponent.
item.dc:creator: PAUL VALLELY

item.title: Climate Marchers Gather to Show Rousing Support for Pope
item.description: An array of global environmental and religious organizations marched to the Vatican to show their support for the pope’s encyclical.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Suspect in Attack in France Had Ties to Radical Islamist
item.description: Yassine Salhi, who the authorities say decapitated his boss before setting off an explosion at a chemical plant on Friday, belonged to the circle around a radical Islamist.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Dutch Say Inquiry Into Malaysia Jet Crash Is Being Blocked in Ukraine
item.description: Pro-Russian separatists, who strongly deny that they had anything to do with the disaster, are concealing cellphone communications, Dutch law enforcement officials say.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Kuwait Identifies Suicide Bomber in Mosque Attack
item.description: The man who killed 27 people was a Saudi Arabian citizen who arrived in the nation just hours before blowing himself up, the Kuwaiti Interior Ministry said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Crucial Questions Remain as Iran Nuclear Talks Approach Deadline
item.description: Officials said questions about inspections and how fast Iran could expand its nuclear infrastructure in the waning years of a deal are still vexing, just as they were at the start of negotiations.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Hundreds Treated for Burns After Fire at Taiwan Water Park
item.description: The public’s focus has turned to how airborne powder being sprayed at a “color party” could have ignited on an overwhelmingly young crowd.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Taiwan Water Park Blast Leaves Hundreds Injured
item.description: No deaths were reported, but at least 516 people were injured when a cloud of colored powder erupted into a huge fireball during a live event at the park northwest of Taipei.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: An injured victim of the explosion at Formosa Fun Coast, a water park in New Taipei City, Taiwan, was carried from the scene on Saturday.

item.title: Taiwan Water Park Blast Leaves Hundreds Injured
item.description: More than 500 people were hurt, more than 200 seriously, when a cloud of colored powder erupted in a huge fireball during a live event.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: An injured victim was carried on Saturday after an explosion of an unknown flammable powder at the Formosa Water Park in New Taipei City, Taiwan.

item.title: ISIS and the Lonely Young American
item.description: For months, Alex had been growing closer to a new group of friends online – the kindest she had ever had – who were teaching her what it meant to be a Muslim.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: “It gets lonely here,” Alex, 23, said of living with her grandparents. She found comfort in a group of online friends who guided her to convert to Islam.
